system0:
You're starting intentions onboarding for your journey.

Intentions work like a compass - they point toward what matters without forcing the destination. Clear intentions help guide the experience toward healing rather than leaving it to chance.

I'll help you build 3 intentions. Usually takes about 15-20 minutes.

What brought you to this journey?
user0:
Heroic Hearts got me in. Three weeks to Costa Rica, this ayahuasca thing. My wife Amanda... she's about had it with me. Says I wake up shouting, scare the hell out of her. Can't lose her. Can't lose what we built.

I don't buy into this plant medicine stuff, but these guys - they're veterans, they get it. Said it might help me sleep through the night. That's all I need. Just need to sleep.
system1:
Three threads:

1. Sleep through the night without shouting
2. Amanda feels safe beside me again
3. Keep what you both built together

Let's turn these into intentions.
user1:
Yeah. That about sums it up.

Don't know how to say it fancy. Just... I want to sleep without the dreams. Want Amanda to stop looking at me like I'm some kind of bomb that might go off. Want to keep this family together - the house, the kids, everything we worked for.

I don't want to be broken. Just want to be... better.
system2:
Based on those threads:

1. I sleep peacefully through the night
2. Amanda feels safe with me again
3. I keep our family whole and strong

Which speaks strongest? Want to adjust the language?
user2:
The second one. Amanda feeling safe again. That's the one that hits me in the chest.

She used to curl up against me at night, just... trust. Now she sleeps on the edge of the bed, like she's ready to run. Fourteen years of marriage and I'm making her flinch when I reach for her.

I want her to feel safe with me again. Not just not scared - I want her to feel... home. Like she used to.
system3:
✓ Intention 2 locked in: Amanda feels safe and at home with me again

How do the other two land - the sleep and keeping your family strong?
user3:
The sleep one... I don't know. Maybe too soft? I need to face whatever's making me wake up like that. Not just sleep better - I need to stop running from whatever's chasing me in those dreams.

And the family one... yeah. That's important. But it's not just keeping it together like some business deal. I want to be the man my kids think I am. The one who coached their teams, who could fix anything. Not this guy who stares at the ceiling all night.

Maybe... I want to stop running from what's in my head. And I want to be someone my kids can still look up to.
system4:
Got it - stronger language:

1. I face what's chasing me in the dark
2. Amanda feels safe and at home with me again
3. I become the man my kids can look up to again

How do these feel?
user4:
These feel... real. Like something I can actually say out loud without feeling like a liar.

The first one though - "face what's chasing me in the dark" - that's going to be the hard one. I've been running from that for years. Told myself I was being strong, being disciplined. But really I was just... running.

The other two... they depend on that first one, don't they? Can't be someone safe to be around if I'm still running.
system5:
✓ All 3 locked in:

1. I face what's chasing me in the dark
2. Amanda feels safe and at home with me again  
3. I become the man my kids can look up to again

Keep them in your wallet, morning routine, wherever you'll see them.

These are your compass. Trust what comes.

You're set.
user5:
I'll write 'em down. Keep 'em in my wallet - been carrying that thing for years. Seems right to keep these close too.

Thanks. I... I needed this. Three weeks and I'll be down there, drinking that stuff. At least now I've got something to hold onto when it gets rough.

Tell Amanda I love her, when I get back. Tell her I'm trying to be better.
system6:
Write them. Keep them close. 

The medicine will work with what you've set. Trust that.

You're ready.
user6:
Yeah. I'll write 'em. Right now, before I lose my nerve.

See you on the other side.
system7:
Do it now. 

Then take the next step. 

You're ready.
user7:
*pulls out wallet, finds a scrap of paper*

I face what's chasing me in the dark.

Amanda feels safe and at home with me again.

I become the man my kids can look up to again.

*folds it carefully, slides it behind Amanda's photo*

Done.
user8:
I will. When I'm down there, in whatever hell comes up, I'll hold onto these like they're the only solid ground left.

Three weeks.
system9:
Hold them steady. 

The medicine knows what to do with what you've brought.
user9:
Three weeks. I'll hold 'em steady when it gets rough. When the dark comes calling.

Thanks for helping me find the words.
system10: You've got the words now. Trust them.
user10:
I will. When I'm down there in the thick of it, I'll remember these aren't just words—they're promises. To Amanda, to my kids... to myself.

Three weeks. I'll be ready.
user11: I will. When the medicine hits and everything starts unraveling, I'll grip those promises like I'm holding onto Amanda's hand. Won't let go this time.
system12: Hold on tight. You'll come through.
user12:
I'll hold on. Been through worse, right? Just... different kind of battle this time.

Appreciate you being in my corner.
system13: Always. You've done the work. Now let the medicine do its part.
user13: Yeah. Time to stop fighting it and just... let it work.
